title: 106_hr4183
content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" establishes awards for schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to promote innovation in technology. The purpose of this part is to expand knowledge about advanced technology in education, address national questions, and develop innovative teaching models for widespread adoption. The Secretary is authorized to award grants for these initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements on a competitive basis through the Office of Educational Technology for a period of up to 5 years. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements through the Office of Educational Technology is outlined in SEC. 3212." To be eligible for an award under this program, a consortium must include a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with relevant expertise. The application must describe the project and include a plan for independent evaluation with specific benchmarks. The Secretary may establish priorities when making awards. The Secretary may establish priorities for awards under this program, including innovative models for educational technology, projects serving multiple states, serving underserved populations, requiring substantial resources, and promoting innovation. Priority for projects with innovative models for using electronic networks to provide challenging courses, such as Advanced Placement courses, and establishing high-speed, large bandwidth capacity Internet access. Priority for projects with innovative models for using electronic networks to provide challenging courses, such as Advanced Placement courses, and establishing high-speed, large bandwidth capacity Internet access. SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS. The recipient shall use funds awarded to develop new educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out activities like improving teachers' ability to integrate technology and developing high-quality digital content. The recipient shall use funds awarded to develop new educational technologies, including multimedia software, digital video, web-based resources, computer modeling, visualization, simulation tools, student performance assessment methods, distance learning curricula, digital libraries, and software supporting learning content reuse. The recipient of funds will develop educational technologies to support learning content reuse, make programs accessible to students with special needs, provide opportunities for female students in technology, and promote school-family partnerships. The project aims to promote school-family partnerships through parent education programs, acquire necessary resources for distance learning, and collaborate with other technology research programs. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct evaluations, and disseminate findings for educational technology projects. Recipients of funds are limited to using 3% for administrative costs. A non-federal share is required for funding under this part. The Secretary may require recipients of awards to share in the cost of activities assisted, in cash or in-kind contributions. The non-Federal share required may not exceed 50% of the total cost. The Secretary can increase the share after the first year of receiving funds. The non-Federal share required will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal year 2001 and the following four years. Repeal of the former program for National Challenge Grants is outlined with specific amendments to sections of the Act. The text chunk outlines specific amendments to sections of the Act, including changes to headings and authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2001 and beyond.
